text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Japan's Sumitomo Construction Co Ltd and its Vietnamese partner, the Thang Long Bridge Construction Corp, have begun work on a new concrete bridge spanning the Chu rive at Do Lien, south of Hanoi.
-- The Vietnam Post and Telecommunications said $1.2 million has been invested to develop the country's telephone card system as part of a masterplan for 1996-2000.

-- The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has opened a resident mission in Hanoi. The largest recipient of the ADB's concessional assistance, Vietnam has been awarded 13 loans totalling $937.5 million and 53 technical assistance grants worth $36.9 million since the Bank resumed assistance to the country in 1993.

-- Esso Eastern Inc, an affiliate of Exxon Corp, signed a joint venture agreement with the state-owned company Cong Ty Dau Tu Mien Dong to build and operate facilities at a site in Ho Chi Minh City. The agreement allows for the distribution and marketing of a range of petroleum products.
-- The State Bank of Vietnam has issued regulations on the procedures for domestic enterprises borrowing from abroad.
-- Dong Xuan, Hanoi's biggest market, officially re-opened on December 19 after being burnt to the ground in 1994.
-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet has demanded the evacuation of residents in the mountainous province of Lai Chau, which was hit by serious flash flooding earlier this year.
-- The Politburo has issued instructions for Communist Party cells to reinforce their anti-drug abuse activities.

-- Chief of the Department for Consular Affairs and Chinese Ambassador Li Jiazhong have signed an agreement on maintaining the Vietnamese consulate in Hong Kong after the territory reverts to China in July 1997.
